page.title: 12BUILDINGS
page.content: The most distinctive feature of the buildings of the area is the locally quarried grey limestone and sandstone. The limited number of pre-17th Century buildings is due to the conversion to stone building with the diminution of the forest of Wensleydale. Outside the villages, the most prominent and profuse type of building is the field barn, a national survey of which is being made at present. The barns were built to a fairly standard pattern to house both stock and fodder. The walls are constructed of limestone with a rubble infill and various courses of through stones. The corners (quoins) are primitive, but effective long and short work of the more-easily-dressed sandstone. Many features of the barns still retain dialect names directly derived from Old Norse.
